description: From Yiddish שלעפּן‎ (shlepn, “to drag”), from Middle High German slepen, from Middle Low German slêpen, from or related to Old High German sleifen (“to drag”) and slifan (“to slip”), from Proto-West Germanic *sleupan.
Compare German schleppen (“to haul”) and its inherited doublet schleifen (“to drag”), Dutch slepen (“to drag”), Danish slæbe (“to haul”).

examples: Sure you can go across town to get that, but it'd be a schlep.

entries.meaning: (informal) A boring person, a drag; a good-for-nothing person.

examples: He must have had a lot of schlep to get such good seats.

verbs.description: schlep (third-person singular simple present schleps, present participle schlepping, simple past and past participle schlepped)

entries.meaning: (transitive, informal) To carry, drag, or lug.
examples: I'm exhausted after schlepping those packages around all day.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, informal) To go, as on an errand; to carry out a task.
examples: I schlepped down to the store for some milk.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, informal) To act in a slovenly, lazy, or sloppy manner.
examples: I just schlepped around the house on Sunday.
